settings.text:
Hiking sandals give you a number of benefits over hiking boots:

  • Freedom â€” Feeling the air on your feet, and not squishing your toes
  • Temperature â€” No more hot feet
  • Water friendly â€” Great for crossing a stream, in a raft or kayak, or on a standup paddle board
  • Cost â€” Up to 75% less
  • Odor â€” Do I need to explain this one? ðŸ˜‰

Not all hiking sandals are the same. Most are actuallyÂ notÂ good for your feet. Why? Well start with this:

Your feet are meant to bend, and flex and move, and FEEL the world.

You want a hiking sandal that lets your feet do that â€” do whatâ€™s natural â€” andÂ donâ€™t weigh a ton.

Check out the Z-Trail, Xero Shoes most popular sandal for hikers and campers. They let your feet do whatâ€™s natural and THREE pairs of these weigh less than one pair of traditional sport sandals.

settings.text:
Weâ€™ve had many customers wear our sandals â€” all the different styles â€” to thru-hike major trails, including the AT, PCT, and Camino.

Even if you donâ€™t wear sandals for hiking, they make a great camp shoe or recovery shoe.

To pick the right hiking sandal, you have 2 decisions to make:

  • Sport sandal style vs. thong style (e.g. our Z-Trail and Z-Trek vs. Genesis and Cloud)
  • More barefoot feeling vs. more protection (Z-Trek, Genesis, Cloud vs. Z-Trail)

NOTE: donâ€™t confuse the thong style sandals with flip flops. Iâ€™ll explain why in the FAQ section further down the page.

Check out our best-selling hiking sandals for men, women and kids. We canâ€™t wait to hear what happens when you get a pair, take them out on your favorite trail and Live Life Feet First!

settings.text: Can you really hike in a sandal?
settings.text_fallback: Share information about your brand with your customers.

settings.text:
Sandals are mankindâ€™s oldest and favorite footwear.

People have been hiking, walking, running â€” LIVING â€” in sandals for thousands of years.

Thereâ€™s no reason you canâ€™t do the same and enjoy the freedom, comfort, and versatility of a hiking sandal.

Weâ€™ve had customers hike every major trail â€” the Appalachian Trail, the Pacific Crest Trail, the Camino de Santiago, and many others.

Some wear their sandals for the whole trail, including our super-thin Genesis. Some use their sandals at the end of the day, as recovery sandals.

We even have cyclists who keep their sandals in their jersey, and slip â€™em on once they get out of their cleats.

settings.text:
Imagine a typical hiking boot or sandal with a thick, stiff sole.

Now imagine that you step on a pointy rock on the inside edge of your shoe.

That point will become a fulcrum, and with a rigid sole your foot canâ€™t move and your ankle will twist.

Frankly, thereâ€™s no amount of ankle support that can stop that. In fact, if it did, the torque would simply move up to your knee, which could be worse!

Now imagine stepping on that same rock with a sole thatâ€™s flexible enough to let your foot bend around the obstacle.

No ankle twisting!

Your body gives you all the support you need ðŸ™‚

settings.text: If the FAQs below donâ€™t answer your questions, contact our Customer Happiness Team atsupport@xeroshoes.comor 303.447.3100 between 9-5, Mountain Time, Mon-Fri (calling is faster).

settings.heading: Are Hiking Boots good for Flat Feet?
settings.answer:
Whatâ€™s good for flat feet is making them strong by USING them.

If your boot doesnâ€™t let your foot flex naturally, then, no.

If it does, then yes.

We make Xero Shoes boots so that your feet can do whatâ€™s natural and support you for life.

settings.heading: Are hiking boots waterproof?
settings.answer:
Not all hiking boots are waterproofâ€¦ even the ones that say â€œwaterproofâ€ on the label!

There are 3 types of construction that have different levels of water resistance.

  1. Some boot uppers use a material thatâ€™s naturally water resistant, or treated with water resistant materials
  2. Some walking boots and hiking boots have a water resistant membrane that keeps some water out
  3. Some have a fully seam-sealed lining (a bootie).

The last is the only fully waterproof option.

And some boots have more than one of those options built in.

For example, theÂ Xero Shoes XcursionÂ has a fully seam sealed inner bootie, a water repelling membrane, and an upper material designed to resist water.

settings.heading: Can Hiking Boots be used as Work Boots?
settings.answer:
It depends on your needs and the requirements of your job.

If you need the protection of a steel toe, then most hiking boots will not suffice.

If your job requires your boots to have protective certification, then no.

settings.heading: Can Hiking Boots be used for Walking?
settings.answer:
The problem is thatÂ mostÂ boots are too stiff for walking.

In fact, if youâ€™re not comfortable walking in hiking boots, you wonâ€™t be comfortable hiking in them.

So, ideally, you want a boot thatâ€™s flexible enough to let your feet move naturally, and wide enough for your toes to spread and splay.

settings.heading: Can I Wear Hiking Boots Without Socks?
settings.answer:
It depends on how sweaty your feet get and what the lining of your boot is made of.

If you have a fully seam-sealed waterproof boot, and you wear it barefoot, be prepared to deal with moisture.

A boot with less waterproofing will breathe more and be better for bare feet

settings.heading: Can you Resole Hiking Boots?
settings.answer:
That depends on the boot.

Contact the manufacturer for details.

Typically, to resole a boot, you need to be able to remove the outsole (the rubber part that hits the ground) without damaging the padding. Or you need to be able to remove the midsole padding as well, while still having a way to reattach the sole.

Xero Shoes boots are not made to be resoled since we donâ€™t use (or need) a midsole that wears out. Plus, our shoes and boots have a 5,000 mile sole warranty.

settings.heading: How are Snow Boots Different than Hiking Boots?
settings.answer:
Typically, there are 3 differences between a boot for hikes vs. one for snow:

  • Snow boots are often taller, coming up higher on the calf or even to the knee
  • Snow boots have different treads to handle ice and snow rather than dirt, gravel, skree, etc.
  • Snow boots will have more insulation and, often, heat reflecting insoles

Snow boots are also often waterproof, or at least water resistant.

Stay tunedâ€¦ in addition to our collection ofÂ hiking, walking and casual boots, Xero Shoes has a snow boot coming out in the 2nd half of 2020!

settings.heading: What makes a good hiking boot?
settings.answer:
Whether youâ€™re a man or woman, hiking boots should be, first and foremost, COMFORTABLE.

That doesnâ€™t mean theyâ€™re cushy, and soft, and full of padding.

It means that at the end of a walk or hike youâ€™re not in a rush to rip off your boots so your feet can feel better.

If youÂ areÂ feeling like that, itâ€™s often because your boots are too stiff and pointy and donâ€™t let your feet move naturally â€” bending, and flexing, and getting FEEDBACK from the ground.

settings.heading: Whatâ€™s the different between a Manâ€™s Hiking Boot and Womanâ€™s Boot?
settings.answer:
Statistically speaking, a hiking boot for men will have a slightly wider toe box and heel compared to a boot for women.

So if youâ€™re a man with a narrow foot, you might consider a â€œwomanâ€™sâ€ boot. And if youâ€™re a woman with a wide foot, consider a â€œmenâ€™sâ€ boot for hiking.

settings.heading: Where Can I Find Walking Boots or Hiking Boots for Wide Feet?
settings.answer:
Well, no shoe or boot is going to fit EVERYONE and all foot shapes.

But we makeÂ Xero ShoesÂ with a wider toe box to let feet spread and splay naturally.

settings.heading: Who makes Vegan Hiking Boots?
settings.answer:
Since many hiking boots are synthetic, many are vegan-friendly, using no animal products.

Xero Shoes hiking boots are 100% vegan friendly.

settings.heading: Why Would I want Lightweight, Minimalist Hiking Boots?
settings.answer:
Simple.

Your feet are meant to bend and move and flex and FEEL the world.

If you donâ€™t let them do their job, the function of balance and agilityÂ triesÂ (unsuccessfully) to move â€œupstreamâ€ into your ankle, your knee, your hip, and your back.

A lightweight, minimalist boot that lets your foot do whatâ€™s natural can take the stress off those upstream joints.

In other words, they let your feet do their job so the rest of your body can do its job.

Donâ€™t neglect the FEELING part â€” you have more nerve endings in your soles than anywhere but your fingertips and lips. Your brainÂ needsÂ that feedback from your feet for proper, efficient, and enjoyable hiking and walking.

Xero Shoesâ€™ bootsÂ are made to let your feet do whatâ€™s natural so you can Live Life Feet First!
